passages.text: Near-term matters in the multi- year elections trade

We are mindful of the "wood for the trees" idiom when it comes to the electricals subgroup; the multi- year out- growth of electrical equipment investment versus GDP is almost as certain as death and taxes, but there are important near- term factors to overlay which drive our ratings and Dec 2026 price targets. We see the most upside risk to consensus at Legrand and in Siemens' SI division, based on our analysis of DC, US office, resi, and discrete automation, as explored herein. We are OW Legrand (from NR) with a PT of €165, which we transfer to Phil Buller and add to our AFL. We are Neutral ABB (from NR) (CHF 55) and Neutral Schneider (from NR) (€220), having published on Siemens at OW (€300) yesterday (link).

Organic top line sitrep: Schneider has evidenced sustained out- growth versus global peers in recent years, thanks to a best- in- class portfolio that was two decades in the making, strong alignment to the fastest growing end markets and geographies, as well as having a relatively low level of exposure to cyclically challenged end markets, specifically discrete automation, autos and resi. On an absolute basis, Schneider's growth remains attractive, but the consensus has captured this and the organic growth of peers is likely to catch up in 2026.

Incremental debt: Due to unfavorable end market exposures in recent years, Legrand's margins have been largely stable on essentially stable volumes. As cyclically depressed, typically high- margin end markets recover alongside growth in DC, we expect positive EPS revisions for Legrand. For Siemens, despite delivering the best margin expansion of its peer set in recent years, and despite there still being a margin gap to aim for, consensus assumes margins in the SI business plateau here, which we cannot reconcile. For Schneider, there are now questions being asked as to why top decile growth hasn't resulted in above- average incremental, and when/how this will change.

Idiosyncratic factors: Siemens' CMD on 9 Dec has been a year in the making and will include key portfolio changes which will drive the investment case and forward multiples. ABB stated its plan to spin out the Robotics business back in April as a dividend- in- kind, which serves as a reason to revisit the equity case ahead of the 18 Nov CMD. As we approach the one- year anniversary of Olivier Blum as Schneider CEO, we see merit in the company scheduling an update.

Relative moves: Schneider investors will understandably push back on our relatively neutral stance given the stock has already lagged peers ytd, most notably, Legrand (SU c- 10% versus LR c+40% ytd). While these moves look extreme, SU was c+30% versus a flat LR in 2024, whilst both had similarly flat earnings revisions. For LR, EPS revisions are now improving relative to SU.
Equity Ratings and Price Targets

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

Analyzing the key growth drivers

The electrification and digitization trends that support the growth algorithms of our coverage are now well documented and generally understood by investors, as evident by the fact that the highest organic growers now broadly align with the highest forward multiples in a relatively linear fashion, as shown below which uses Bloomberg consensus forecasts + a JPM overlay of Siemens excluding SHL. In our view, the shorter cycle cyclical factors are oftentimes underestimated and should be an important focus area as we look ahead to the balance of the year and into 2026.
Figure 1: EPS growth (CY24-27 CAGR) vs. P/E (CY26)
Source: J.P. Morgan, Bloomberg Finance L.P.
Figure 2: EBIT growth (CY24-27 CAGR) vs. EV/EBIT (CY26)
Source: J.P. Morgan, Bloomberg Finance L.P.

The Robotics & Discrete Automation business area had a \(15\%\) Operational EBITA margin target. However, the business has only achieved the \(15\%\) margin or better in one year since 2017, and this was in 2017. Only six quarters in this period have seen the \(15\%\) margin target achieved. Consistent with the steps to improve the profitability under CEO Rosengren, the Operational EBITA margin did increase from the 2020 trough but stalled in the \(10 - 11\%\) range for two years before then reaching \(14.6\%\) in 2023.
We expect improved disclosures and new outlook guidance at the CMD for this business, which will of course be key given the imminent spin scheduled for Q2 2026.
There are also several reports that track fundamentals here; we have summarised the key metrics from Cushman/Wakefield below.
Figure 5: Under construction
Source: Cushman & Wakefield
Figure 6: Vacancy rates
Source: Cushman & Wakefield

JPM has built a proprietary DC funnel, which tracks DC build outs in the US starting since Jan 2023. The data continues to show striking growth and is now standing at c295GW, finishing Q2'25 with additions totaling 51 GW (vs. 40 GW in 2Q24). This translates into a c120% y/y addition in H1'25 and a c30% y/y increase in Q2. Importantly, these reference points sit either side of the DeepSeek news which shook the electricals sub- group at the start of the year, but we continue to see significant additions post DeepSeek, at c110GW. We believe these datapoints to be the cornerstone of the DC debate, and they imply clear, strong growth ahead which supports our bullish stance.

Adjusting for large land deals (>1,000 acres) and assuming zero build- outs for them, the number still stands out at a considerable c165GW. This compares to an installed base of 20 GW in US as of 2022, with 2- 2.5 GW being added in 2023 and between 3- 5 GW in 2024. We assume that the entire funnel will not come to fruition, but even after applying a 50% haircut, the number is significantly above the most bullish estimates we see from third party sources. By state, Texas has overtaken Virginia with recent outsized multi- GW project announcements to become the state with the most projects, while Georgia, Ohio and Arizona are newer markets now witnessing substantial investment.
Figure 7: Timing of newsflow shows a material inflection that accelerated in 2Q24 and has remained above average in 3Q24 onwards and shows no slowing even after DeepSeek news
Source: J.P. Morgan database and estimates, sourced from DCD and DC Knowledge
Figure 8: MW planned by state Megawatts
Source: J.P. Morgan database and estimates, sourced from DCD and DC Knowledge

In short, as much as we appreciate that our DC- exposed names will see their multiples ebb and flow alongside DC capex headlines from the hyperscalers on a quarter- to- quarter basis, it is hard to envisage a scenario where DC growth doesn't continue to be strongly accretive to the growth outlook of the electricals for several years, most likely in the \(20 - 40\%\) range, varying from one company to another based on base effects, from one quarter to the next. We do not believe there will be a material difference between the gray space and the white space of DC's on a multi- year basis, given the relatively linear relationship between the \(S / MW\) of electrical content in both areas.

In our EU coverage, we estimate Legrand and Schneider to have the highest direct gearing to DC at c. \(24\%\) of revenue, with ABB at c. \(6\%\) and Siemens at c. \(2\%\) , which would increase to c. \(3\%\) post SHL deconsolidation. Outside of the four walls of the DC, we assume Siemens, Schneider and ABB's respective Electrification divisions have double- digit exposure to wider DC infrastructure spending, further supporting growth in the medium term. However, in some instances, this is now more reflected in the near- term consensus than it was say 12- 18 months ago.

Delving into the US 'core office' marketTotal U.S. office spending was up between \(1\%\) and \(4\%\) over the past few years, within which DC grew in the \(40\% - \text{plus}\) range and now represents \(43\%\) of all US office spend. Clearly, this implies that the balance, which we would refer to as 'core office', has been in significant contraction territory for an extended period. Whilst core office is still tough, there are reasons for sequential optimism, which we explore below. This topic is most relevant for Legrand, who disclosed that their US office activity (which we assume to have previously been margin accretive) is down some \(40\%\) in volume terms. Whilst peers have also faced headwinds from this end market, it is most material for Legrand.
Figure 9: Office Construction Spending Left: Absolute Spend, Right: % Y/Y
Figure 10: Office Construction Spending Growth

Employment: We define "office- related" employment as the total number of employees in financial services firms and professional business services, as defined by the monthly BLS reports. This is a good proxy for demand for commercial office space and has correlated well with private office construction historically. Employment growth for these verticals has been flatish to down slightly since the beginning of '24.
Figure 11: Office Construction Spending vs. Office Employee Growth (Historical View)
Source: BLS, U.S. Census
Figure 12: Office Construction Spending vs. Office Employee Growth (Near-Term View)
Source: BLS, U.S. Census
Figure 13: "Core" Office Construction Spending vs. Office Employee Growth Left: Construction Y/Y, Right: Employee Y/Y
Source: BLS,U.S.Census

We also look at public office/commercial construction compared to government employment data. Total government employment turned positive in May '21 for the first time since Apr '20 and has remained positive in the LSD range. Government employment was up \(\sim 1\%\) in Apr/May '25, inching down gradually since the beginning of '24.
Figure 14: Public Office/Commercial Construction Spending vs. Gov't Employee Growth (Historical View)
Figure 15: Public Office/Commercial Construction Spending vs. Gov't Employee Growth (Near-Term View)

Vacancies & Rents: We use data from CB Richard Ellis, reported quarterly (methodology may differ from other third- party data sources like REIS). This has been a good supply/demand indicator, measuring vacancy rates. The data here is meant to represent national averages and has been a good indicator for the overall market, though we acknowledge that supply- demand is ultimately very local in nature.

- Office vacancy rates have remained stable at \(\sim 19\%\) from Q2'24 to Q1'25, which is materially above historical peaks of \(\epsilon 8\%\) . These currently elevated rates appear to have peaked and imply limited downside versus considerable upside as it pertains to potential renovation activity at this juncture, in our view.
Figure 16: US Office Vacancy Rates vs Private Office Construction Left: Private office construction Y/Y, Right: Office Vacancy
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P., C.B. Richard Ellis
Figure 17: Office Vacancy Rates
Source:C.B.Richard Ellis

Composite indicator: Our composite indicator for office space is based on a combination of employment growth (new demand) and the absolute level of vacancy (excess supply). This was down \(37\%\) \(36\%\) \(35\%\) \(35\%\) in \(Q2^{\prime}24\) \(Q3^{\prime}24\) \(Q4^{\prime}24\) and \(Q1^{\prime}25\) , respectively. Whilst still tough, sequentially speaking we see more upside than downside for US office renovation in the data.
Figure 18: JPM Composite Indicator vs. Core Office Construction Spending Left: Construction % Y/Y, Right: Composite Indicator
Source: U.S. Census, J.P. Morgan. Indicator Components: Office - Related Employment Growth, Office Vacancy Rates.
JLL recently published its 1Q Office Market Dynamics report and we outline the major developments below:

- In Q1 2025, leasing volume reached 50.4 million square feet, marking a growth of \(15\%\) compared to Q1 2024, despite a moderate slowdown from post-pandemic highs in Q4. Over the past 12 months, leasing volume reflects \(89\%\) of typical pre-pandemic activity levels.- Occupancy losses returned as net absorption fell to -8.1 million square feet in Q1, largely due to federal lease terminations, contractor sublease additions, and inventory removals.- Direct asking rents remained largely stable, with a \(0.14\%\) quarter-over-quarter growth, as landlords maintained or increased rents, with significant discounts being rare.

- Conversion and redevelopment volume remained high at the start of 2025, but completions fell to their lowest level in over a decade, with only 3.5 million square feet delivered.- Overall, U.S. office inventory declined by more than 10 million square feet and is projected to fall by an additional 40 million square feet by the end of the decade.- In Q1, groundbreaking were limited, with less than 1 million square feet initiated, and the development pipeline has decreased by 78% since 2019, totaling 31 million square feet nationwide.- Major private-sector employers have enforced full-time return-to-office policies, boosting office utilization rates and decreasing hybrid and remote roles. On average, Fortune 100 companies require 3.74 days in the office per week.- Office investment volume surged by more than 60% increase compared to the first quarter of 2024, marking the largest year-over-year growth since the slowdown in sales began in 2022.
On the forward outlook, the report noted the following:

- The office market's occupier-led recovery continued in Q1, but new risks from macroeconomic uncertainty have emerged, including a double-digit decline in S&P 500 equity prices and prolonged equity market volatility, which have been linked to reduced office leasing and increased sublease space.- Downsizing rates have improved significantly over the past year, and increased adoption of office attendance mandates has prompted several large occupiers to expand, suggesting reduced occupancy loss and potential positive net absorption and declining vacancy rates in the year's second half.- A promising sign in Q1 was improved capital markets liquidity for the office sector and tentative distress level improvements, allowing landlords to invest in concessions and upgrades for Class A buildings, signaling a potential acceleration in new development, crucial for supporting a demand recovery as limited high-end space hampers transaction volume.- Attendance rates and average weekly requirements are expected to grow incrementally throughout 2025, driven by a softening labor market that shifts leverage to employers.- Renewal activity is anticipated to remain high, with relocation options, especially upgrades for Class A tenants, becoming limited in some markets.- Overall inventory is projected to decline by approximately 50 million square feet by the decade's end, based on current conversion and redevelopment proposals in major markets, with potential for further decline if inventory removals remain high and new development slows.- Expansionary leases set to take occupancy throughout the year should lead to improved absorption and vacancy rates in the second half.

Net net, in our view the US office market remains in a clear state of flux, but the risk/ reward following such a protracted downturn, and with the employment data suggesting the balance is shifting more towards employers to push for a return to offices, the risk reward on a 12- 24 month we see as clearly favorable. Pleasingly, it appears that consensus is assuming zero growth in this market for e.g. Legrand across the forecast period, which is helpful to the equity case and supports our OW rating.

Given the energy intensity of DC's and the pressure these assets put on existing infrastructure, there is an argument that the current tightness of the energy equation could be loosened by addressing the significant inefficiencies that exist in buildings, which still account for c. \(30\%\) of all final energy consumption, as detailed by the IEA. Of course, it is easier for e.g. MSFT to reopen the Three Mile Island nuclear facility than single- handedly fix the inefficient global housing stock.

Payback periods for energy efficiency investments remain attractive at typically less than three years, but this once important topic for investors has understandably been overshadowed by the downturn in the overall European residential market since c.2022. That said, the performance of our coverage has typically held up better than the underlying market, due to the increasing electrical content per building versus history.

We are increasingly confident of an improved residential investment outlook in 2026 on the basis of the most recent e.g. new housing starts data from France and new resi construction volume data coming out of Germany, for example.The data supports the commentary from the recent Q3 reporting season where we heard multiple management teams, including the distributors, refer to green shoots in European resi. In parallel to what should be an end market driven recovery from depressed levels, there is reason to assume that the electrical content per building (which improves overall efficiency) should see incrementally higher growth than the end market itself.

The industrial automation / general manufacturing end markets have faced significant headwinds over the past two years, in the aftermath of the exaggerated boom postCOVID due to supply chain challenges and associated distributor over- stocking. The subsequent hiatus since 2022 in most key geographies has led to significant volume pressure for our coverage, notably Siemens DI, ABB RDA, Schneider IA and Rexel.
This prolonged downturn is showing signs of bottoming and is an encouraging setup as we look ahead to 2026, as shown below.
Figure 23: Euro Area Manufacturing PMI Latest data point (Jul 2025): 49.8
Figure 24: US Manufacturing PMI
Source: S&P Global, ISM.

Aggregating the data to our JPM Global PMI proxy (see Figure 26) would imply a relatively flattish overall demand at the global level, which is in- keeping with commentary from the recent Q3 reporting period, where we heard general commentary that the destocking process having now ended, but that the absolute level of demand remains somewhat subdued, for the time being, but with improving sequential momentum looking ahead into 2026.

China and automotive end markets in particular are key to global manufacturing activity, and it is unclear what the pace of change from here will ultimately be. We also note that the domestic China players have improved their offerings prior to and during the downturn, so it is unclear how market shares evolve during the recovery phase. That said, we see limited downside risk to the overall demand environment given the headwinds we have seen across our coverage in recent years, and we are now seeing strong order growth from China for Siemens DI (+31%, +41% in Q3'25, Q2'25, respectively), from low levels. Consensus now models a recovery in 2026, which we think is credible, although it is difficult to have conviction of upside to consensus.
Figure 25: NBS China Manufacturing PMI
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P.
Figure 26: JPM Global PMI
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P.

As shown in the charts below, most notably in Figure 28, consensus forecasts a relatively strong recovery in the coming two years after a challenging period over the past two years. We are essentially inline with consensus growth forecasts for our automation- exposed coverage, however we have relatively low conviction when it comes to the potential to beat current market expectations, absent clearer evidence in the data.

That said, cyclical recoveries are typically powerful and hard to time from an investment standpoint, but it is rarely better to be late than early when it comes to stock selection in these situations.

There are many moving parts that need to be considered for our overall coverage, which we have summarized as succinctly as possible in the table below. Overall, PMIs have sequentially improved in Europe, the US and China. Construction data-points remain mixed with some positive signs in European Resi, European Non-Res and US Non-Res (in particular core office), collectively making us more bullish as we look ahead towards the exit rate of 2025 into 2026 for much of our European coverage, both in and outside of the electricals sub-group, which is the focus of this note.
Figure 31: Summary of Key Data
Source: Various. Note that green shows month-on-month improvement, while red shows month-on-month weakness.

In this section, we carry out a global benchmarking exercise to contextualize how the European peers sit versus each other as well as US peers, in order to show not just which companies are best positioned from an end market standpoint (as covered in the previous section), but how they compare from a valuation, growth, returns and on various quality metrics. We note that at present earnings growth seems to be the primary driver of share prices and valuation multiples, as inferred from the linear relationship on a PEG adjusted chart; however, returns on capital and other efficiency metrics should of course still matter in the medium to long term.

The charts below show the current level of 12- month forward valuation versus the past five years of valuation ranges, plus or minus one standard deviation. The data suggests that most of our coverage is hovering around the high end of these ranges, which on the one hand is hard to justify given just how strong some end markets have been over this look back period, but on the other hand is understandable given the continued momentum from electrical trends, including DC, in addition to cyclically recovering end markets, most notably Resi and theoretically, US core office and industrial automation / IP or PMI driven sectors.

The operational performance of ABB today is unrecognizable versus five years ago. Former CEO Bjorn Rosengren and current CFO Timo Ihamuotila transformed the company and, based on the facts rather than speculation, it appears the business was passed on to Morten Wierod in good shape when he took the helm a year ago. We disagree with the 6x Sell / UW ratings on the stock, as market positioning continues to impress along with strong financials, and we see little if any evidence to suggest that the strategy of peers to chase high multiple software M&A delivers value for shareholders. That said, we do not see any material upside or downside to consensus estimates and the valuation we see as fair for the growth on offer, as opposed to cheap. Hence, we move to a Neutral rating (from NR) and a PT of CHF55.

We would push back on the underinvestment argument: In a prior role, we too harboured concerns that the focus on costs to expand margins and buybacks over R&D and M&A (relative to EU peers) could have left the company in a situation in the post- Rosen- gren era as being underinvested. We see no tangible evidence of this and instead would posit that EU peers could have been more efficient on R&D, as ABB and its US peers were, and the expensive software M&A spree of peers over the past decade shows little sign of valuation creation for shareholders, at this juncture. The company has now upped R&D and capex to better reflect the demand environment, and the core growth in end markets supports higher investment and continues to support solid core earnings growth.

Important CMD but maybe not a big catalyst: After 12 months in the post, we look forward to Morten Wierod's first major CMD on 18 Nov where we expect him to lay out his strategic call for the coming years. We expect this to be an evolution of medium- term targets, as opposed to there being a material change to the growth algorithm, which in our view is already embedded in the consensus. With the spin- out of the Robotics business ( \(c4\%\) of group profits) already well flagged, it is unclear to us if this event will be a material catalyst for the shares, albeit we see it as an important update for LO investors.

E- Mobility could be incremental: The planned spin- out of this business (first announced in late 2021 for IPO in 2022) was delayed on a number of occasions, due to unfavorable financial market conditions in the first instance, and higher than expected investments / costs to scale the business towards breakeven in c2023. This topic appears to be of limited interest to investors at present, but could serve as a small positive (LSD) in the event it moves higher up the agenda as we approach the CMD.

Robotics deeper- dive: With the core RemainCo growth drivers well documented in the front section of this note, we seek to provide a deeper dive on the Robotics business herein, given the imminent spin (scheduled for Q2 2026) noting that the last ABB spinout (ACLN SW) has turned out to be a high- returning investment.

Forecasts and Valuation. We model overall organic growth in the 2025 to 2027 timeframe of c. \(6\%\) driven by the Electrification division, resulting in c. \(9\%\) average growth in company defined operating EBITA. Relative to consensus, we are \(0\%\) \(1\%\) and \(2\%\) ahead in the 2025 and 2027 timeframes, respectively. We set our December 2026 Price Target at CHF55 via an 18x EV/EBITA target multiple applied to our normalized 2027 forecasts using a reverse DCF.

ABB is the most transparent and well- managed business within our coverage, providing detailed quarterly reporting across its four business areas, with a seemingly relentless focus on portfolio management for the purposes of shareholder value creation.

While the company currently reports across four business areas, this will change to three upon the spin- out of the Robotics business. In our view, ABB is best broken down between the two industry drivers of electrification and automation exposure, akin to the Schneider EM and IA split and the SI and DI split of Siemens, as we covered in the earlier benchmarking section. The current business structure is shown below.
Figure 57: ABB - Revenue by segment 2024; excl. Corporate & Other
Source: Company reports.
Figure 58: ABB - Operational EBITA by segment 2024; excl. Corporate & Other
Source: Company reports.

ABB's Electrification business has shown strong growth in the post- COVID era alongside peers, with strong pricing actions to ensure gross and operating margin expansion overall, as opposed to chasing lower margin project revenue, which we support. Given the significant snap- back in earnings of the RDA business, which is embedded in consensus forecasts, if accurate, this could imply growing interest in this business ahead of the planned spin- out of Robotics in Q2 2026. We expect further disclosure and guidance on this area at the CMD.

The robotics business is the primary portfolio differentiator between EU peers Siemens and Schneider, which we have covered extensively in the benchmarking section of this note. For many years, ABB had argued that there were synergies in being able to offer robotics as part of its wider automation solutions, but the view from management now (which we share) is that those synergies are somewhat limited, hence the planned spinout, which was announced on April 17, 2025.

The intention is for the business to start trading as a separately listed company during the second quarter of 2026 and to be listed on the Swiss Stock Exchange. If shareholders decide in favor of the proposal, the spin- off is planned to be done through a share distribution, whereby ABB Ltd.'s shareholders will receive shares in the company to be listed (working name "ABB Robotics") as a dividend in- kind in proportion to their existing shareholding. Given the planned spin and the unique nature of the division, we will provide an overview of the business herein and anticipate more disclosure with the CMD to enable higher fidelity analysis.

Despite robotics being highly engineered pieces of equipment, which are also more tangible products for generalist investors to understand than e.g. motion controllers and electrical switches, the competitive intensity for robotics is high, margins are structurally lower than the ABB group average, and it is ultimately a tough end market to navigate. We assume the outlook for the robotics business is likely to be brighter as a standalone entity than it is as part of the ABB portfolio, which was also the case with Accelleron (ACLN SW) which was spun- out of ABB in H2'22.

- To date, the robotics business has been reported as part of the Robotics and Discrete Automation (RDA) division, and represented approximately 2/3rds of the divisional revenue. The company has not disclosed the financial profile of this business on a time series basis, but has now shared that Robotics has c. 7,000 employees and in 2024 generated revenues of \(2.3bn\) (c. 7% of the ABB group) and had an Operational EBITA margin of 12.1% (i.e. c. \(280m\) of EBITA or c4% of FY24 group profit).- Whilst being in a more difficult end market than the RemainCo ABB, the Robotics positioning is strong, holding the number 2 market position and competing against Fanuc, Teradyne, KUKA and Yaskawa. Whilst the peer set typically has broader exposures, their valuations for FY27 typically range from c. 13x to 18x EV/EBITA, which compares to ABB which trades at the mid to high end of that range. In short, this would not be overly material from an accretion or rerating standpoint, but we see this as a positive tidy-up that will see modestly higher group margins and marginally less cyclicality for the RemainCo, as well as an interesting standalone mid-cap Swiss industrial asset for investors to consider in the future.- As of Q1 2026, the Machine Automation division, which together with ABB Robotics currently forms the Robotics & Discrete Automation business area, will become part of the Process Automation business area. The Machine Automation business holds a leading position in the high-end segment for solutions based on PLCs, IPCs, servo motion, industrial transport systems and vision and software.

ABB Robotics in a nutshellABB manufactures robots, Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs) which move loads in a diverse range of industries, robotics application cells and smart systems, field services, spare parts, digital services and software. Financial information is limited, but we were told at the announcement that revenue was \(\) 2.3\$ bn in 2024, 70% of which were direct.

Prior to any additional disclosure, we are only able to interrogate the financial profile of the RDA business as a whole, however given it represents c. 2/3rds of revenue, the overall takeaways we assume are similar. The development of the Robotics & Discrete Automation financials has been somewhat contrasting to the other three ABB divisions between 2020 and 2024. Unlike the other three business areas, where margins have gradually increased and are currently close to peaks, Robotics & Discrete Automation's margins improved from the cyclical 2020 COVID- hit lows, but have struggled to fully recover.
Figure 75: Robotics & Discrete Automation - Quarterly financial development (Q1'20-Q2'25)
Source: Company reports.

The development in the financials follows two clear halves, a period from the 2020 cyclical low with significant growth in orders and sales accompanied by margin expansion, followed by significant pressure on the orders, sales and margins lines as the market deteriorated. It is hard, in the face of the moves in the market, to really assess how much has changed and how much of the improvement and then pressure was a function of just another cycle.

- Improved mix 
- The business has evolved to be more product focused and tilted away from challenging and lower margin systems/project type work. Between 2019 and 2023, products added 
-500bp of share of sales (moving from 
-55% to 
-60%), all at the expense of solutions & systems work (falling from 
-35% to 
-25%). The larger project work would typically involve turnkey work that would require a lot of non-ABB products which ABB would have to source and make only a pass-through margin on. The work today is based much more heavily around ABB's core product, a richer mix of business as well as being lower risk. In addition, the business has been able to increase the share of higher-margin service revenues.- Price 
- As seen elsewhere in the ABB group, a focus on pricing has contributed to the margin development with a focus on pricing for the value provided for the customer. The pricing development is such that prices in 2023 were running 
-5-15% ahead of the 2020 level with progress across all four identified segments.
Figure 76: ABB Robotics & Discrete Automation - Price index products (Indexed to 100 in 2020)
Source: Company Reports 2023 Capital Markets Day.

- Management has talked to 'pricing maturity' using tools to manage price changes: software to provide real-time transparency, pricing analytics and segmentation to ensure appropriate pricing across markets and products. Also helpful has been a focus on local pricing and local pricing decisions, even with global oversight this helps the local team price for the value actually provided to the customers. This local pricing, supplemented by the data on pricing, also allows for flexibility as the market changes, important given the cyclicality seen in this market.- Quality 
- Quality has improved significantly since 2024. On the company's 'defects per million' measure (for robots), the defects have fallen from >40k per million to

Previously, ABB stated that the underlying growth of the Robotics & Discrete Automation market would be \(c8\%\) . This was said to be underpinned by a modest CAGR in machine automation and stronger growth rates across the robotics space, notably in non- auto end markets and in autonomous mobile robots (robots that can understand and move through the operating environment without being limited by being directly overseen by an operator).

The growth rates presented below were outlined in late- 2023, which disappointed in the 2023- 2025 timeframe, but we would suggest the long term drivers for growth are generally structural (higher wage costs, ageing demographics) which have been impacted by cyclical factors of late.
Figure 77: ABB's assessment of the Robotics & Discrete Automation market
Source: Company Reports 2023 Capital Markets Day.

The division was traditionally very heavily automotive focused and, consistent with the evolution of the automation industry more generally, originally close to \(100\%\) of the product would have been sold to automotive customers. Even 10 years ago, automotive would have represented two- thirds of divisional sales. The customer base and exacting standards make this a challenging market and profitability is generally lower than other segments. However, being present in the automotive market speaks to the quality of the offering and the technical competence, and this works as effectively a stamp of approval for other industries. The strong position that ABB therefore has in automotive provides a springboard for growth in other markets.
The relative maturity of robotization varies hugely across industries, providing a long runway in some markets.
Figure 78: ABB assessment of robotization maturity by segment
Source: Company Reports, Capital Markets Day 2023.

ABB's Robotics & Discrete Automation sales have grown in machine builders and general industry (both \(>20\%\) of sales) and consumer and service robotics and electronics (both \(\sim 10\%\) of sales). When working to enter new markets, Robotics & Discrete Automation sets up an incubator team (can be \(\sim 10\) people) and then looks to target the opportunity.

The level of robot usage varies enormously across countries. Penetration rates in Asian countries - notably South Korea, Singapore and Japan - as well as some Western countries - Germany and the US - are multiples of the global average. Perhaps most significantly, the level of robots in large but developing countries, including India, is well below the global average. ABB believes they are the market leader in India with (as of 2023) a \(\sim 14\%\) market share in robotics and number 3 in machine automation with a \(\sim 15\%\) market share. We would expect penetration rates in developing countries to increase dramatically in the coming years, a potentially material opportunity for the large robotics players, including ABB, given the same drivers of labour challenges, flexibility, automation and cost reduction.

Increased penetration of robotics in a wider range of countries would also have the potential to better smooth the cyclicality that is observable at present. Whilst China is still likely to remain by far the dominant global market - currently \(\sim 50\%\) with the ambition to double the number of robots - outsized growth in some of these currently smaller but rapidly growing markets could provide a needed balance to the market.
Figure 79: Robots installed per 10k employees
Source: Company reports.

The business now spends \(\sim 60\%\) of total R&D on software, a focus on differentiating the offering. Management sees the addition of AI and greater software capability as key to differentiating the product offering and enabling greater capability of the robotics offering. ABB has developed a suite of software products with, for example RobotStudio, leading to shorter programming times, shorter cycle times and lower energy consumption. Management believes \(\sim 80\%\) of the product is now software/AI enabled.

The R&D teams work with customers on the development programmes; R&D teams are not just left to work on own projects, a likely large efficiency saving, removing the likelihood of vanity projects or similar. This collaboration with customers also joins the sales/account management team with the R&D effort, aligning goals. Similarly, the R&D teams will work with start- ups, a symbiotic relationship providing ABB with access to the newest ideas and the start- up the scale of a recognized market leader.

ABB is always clear that the local Chinese competition typically plays in the more commoditized part of the market, the 'M3' part of the market. ABB plays in the M1 - the premium, differentiated part of the market - and M2 - lower complexity but segment focused and localized portfolio - segments. Greater advancements of the software help to further extend the technology lead and/or create further barriers to entry in the M1 segment, although we see the domestic offering as having become significantly more sophisticated of late.
Figure 80: Robotics & Discrete Automation - Operational EBITA margin (Q1'17-Q2'25)
Source: Company reports.

The Robotics & Discrete Automation business area had a \(15\%\) Operational EBITA margin target. However, the business has only achieved the \(15\%\) margin or better in one year since 2017, and this was in 2017. Only six quarters in this period have seen the \(15\%\) margin target achieved. Consistent with the steps to improve the profitability under CEO Rosengren, the Operational EBITA margin did increase from the 2020 trough but stalled in the \(10 - 11\%\) range for two years before then reaching \(14.6\%\) in 2023.
We expect improved disclosures and new outlook guidance at the CMD for this business, which will of course be key given the imminent spin scheduled for Q2 2026.

Given the end market mix and cyclical recovery factors covered earlier in this note, we see there being considerably more upside than downside to consensus earnings growth in the 2026 to 2027 timeframe, supporting our OW rating on the stock. Whilst Legrand does not have a CMD on the calendar, in our view this is not necessary for the stock to "work", given the improved run- rate into 2026 on an operational basis, and the recent pivot from management in terms of accepting that end markets (not least DC) are indeed accelerating. We move to an OW rating (from NR), with a Street- high Dec- 26 price target of €165 and add the stock on our Analyst Focus List.

Datacenter growth will continue and support growth. Accounting for c. \(24\%\) of group sales, Legrand's DC exposure is now the highest in the sector alongside Schneider. Whilst there has been increasingly more debate on the sustainability of DC growth since Deepseek, we expect the strong momentum to continue. US and EU electrical infrastructure has been underinvested for decades and a step- change in power demand has put increased pressure on the existing infrastructure, not least helped by the proliferation of AI. We are bullish on the DC theme and see Legrand as the preferred play over Schneider (N) at this juncture.

Residential showing signs of hope. European resi datapoints are finally turning more positive with both French housing starts and German construction volume now up y/y, albeit from depressed levels. Broader peer commentary has suggested green shoots in Europe, with some expecting signs of a recovery starting in H2. Aside from a broader market improvement, Legrand will continue to benefit from higher electrical content per building (which improves overall efficiency) which should see incrementally higher growth than the end market itself. US remains weak but comps are becoming easier.

US Office approaching a bottom: After COVID- 19, the hopes of a full recovery in office demand are all but zero. However, the return to work momentum has been stronger than was perhaps anticipated at the height of "WFH". The datapoints and peer commentary are now pointing to a bottoming in this market. Whilst we do not expect this to be a strong growth contributor in the next few years, after a \(40\%\) volume decline already which was previously offsetting the strength in DC, the risk/reward is now firmly in positive territory, in our view. Consensus is implicitly assuming zero growth in this market, which is helpful to the equity case and supports our OW rating.

Credit is due for the M&A roll- up strategy: Unlike Schneider and Siemens, Legrand has a clear track record of successful M&A at disciplined prices, typically buying small and lower margin assets at discounted valuations, and making them better, as opposed to paying debatable prices for software companies. This capital allocation discipline has been overshadowed by relative growth versus peers in prior years, which we believe should change as growth accelerates into and during 2026.

Valuation and forecasts: Over 2025- 2027E, we model organic growth of c. \(7\%\) with c. \(5\%\) driven by datacenter growth alone but also supported by positive growth in both res and non- res. Consensus assumes broadly stable margins, as do we given it is essentially in keeping with management commentary that is unlikely to change, but we see this as a source of incremental upside. We set our December 2026 Price Target at €165 using a 20x EV/EBITA target multiple applied to our normalized 2027 forecasts using a reverse DCF, which is justified on the basis of the margins which are unwaveringly in excess of \(20\%\) .

Unlike peers that straddle both electrical and automation end markets, Legrand is arguably the purest play to the electrical theme and the simplest to understand. The business is well- managed, deeply transparent, and has navigated the difficult resi and US core office markets as well as we could have hoped in recent years.

We have found over time that many consensus forecasts extrapolate recent rates of growth and increments into the forecast period, which in the case of Legrand, we believe overlooks the drivers of flattish growth over the lookback period. Strong growth of DC has essentially offset significant headwinds in US core office, and European resi, resulting in a flattish business overall with immaterial earnings momentum. Looking forward, we see a sequentially improving outlook in resi and core office in parallel to continued growth in DC. Whilst this is starting to be captured in top line estimates, we see further upside from leverage, which is not yet in estimates.

Schneider Electric is the undisputed global leader in the overall supply of electrical products, solutions, services and software, as evident by the sustained organic outgrowth versus peers on a multi- year basis. We believe the relative outperformance of the top line is sustainable in the current end markets, given the portfolio and, following a sustained period of share price underperformance, we see immaterial downside risk to owning the shares at current levels in absolute terms. Notwithstanding, for the shares to "work" there are questions to be answered regarding both the lack of leverage and the recent speed of execution on price and cost. Absent a CMD to address these items, it is hard to envisage the shares outperforming, while Siemens and ABB do have CMD's which look set to steal the Schneider limelight, hence our Neutral rating. Our Dec- 26 price target of €220 used a c19x EV/EBITA target multiple applied to our normalized 2027 forecasts using a reverse DCF.

Organic growth is not in question: The Energy Management business of Schneider, which represents \(80\%\) of group profits and sales (and more like \(90\% +\) of the investment case, in our view), has outgrown global peers on a consistent basis for five straight years, thanks to the then visionary portfolio actions of former CEO (now Chairman) Jean- Pascal Tricoire in the 2005 to 2019 period. Notwithstanding, the relative top line growth argument is widely appreciated and is a key reason why there are no Sell or UW ratings.

Increments need to be explained: The outperformance on the top line has not resulted in outperformance in absolute EBIT terms, due to continued investment in R&D, Capex and headcount additions alongside growth. Whilst we are advocates for investing in future growth, the rate of expected returns on current investments needs to be addressed, ideally in a comprehensive CMD, given the lack of incremental drop through versus peers appears to be somewhat structural.

Management change coincides with execution change: Investors are now asking what changes resulted in the uncharacteristic miss in Q1 and otherwise uninspiring H1 results, and are arriving at the view that this is the first full reporting period under CEO Olivier Blum, who was appointed in Q4 last year after the unexpected immediate dismissal of Peter Herweck, who himself had been in place for just 18 months. From the outside, it is hard to know if there is an operational issue that needs to be addressed or if it is one of communications, but we are confident things will improve.

Relative disclosure: The compelling narrative of Schneider has driven the multiple since pre- COVID times, due to a decision to reduce disclosure in an effort to move the investment community towards a longer term investment horizon over quarterly prints and a SOTP valuation methodology employed at the time. However, with the 20- quarter beat- and- raise track record now finished, investors are increasingly asking for improved disclosure. In our view, Schneider is the most opaque company in our coverage in the context of its absolute market cap scale.

Capital allocation debate: We have noted over time that the market has been forgiving of Schneider's capital allocation decisions so long as the company was delivering operationally ahead of market expectations. However, investors are now questioning the multiple paid in the acquisition of the Indian JV minorities and wondering what may be next.

Valuation and rating: For the \(10 - 15\%\) growth on offer for the 22x P/E multiple on 2026 estimates, the shares appear inexpensive. However, we see immaterial upside or downside risk to consensus forecasts on a 12 month view, absent M&A.
As evident from the below, the disclosure is relatively limited in terms of the breakdown in profitability between the business and subsegments.

Stronger growth outlook today vs history. The group is positioned to be a beneficiary of a number of the structural growth drivers we identify at the sector level. We expect the group to deliver sustainably strong organic growth in the coming years as it has in the recent past.

Portfolio actions and self- help largely complete. The ABB portfolio is now in a good place, and the multi- year self- help efforts have unequivocally resulted in a higher quality business today. However, the spin- out of Robotics, and potentially the EV business are positive, albeit relatively small in terms of the value creation they will create, given how well the shares have performed over recent years, in our view.

Competition for capital in the electricals space - we see more upside elsewhere. The relative attractiveness of the electricals space and the improved quality not just of ABB but also peers, both in Europe and the US, makes this a competitive space for shareholder capital. We recognise ABB's attractions, but, at present, we see greater upside elsewhere amongst our large- cap electricals, namely Siemens and Legrand, and as a result, rate ABB at Neutral.
Our December 2026 Price Target is based on a reverse DCF valuation. The target multiple is 18x EV/adj. EBITA applied to our 2027 forecasts.

·A quality franchise. We believe Legrand is a high-quality franchise offering many favourable, long-term characteristics, including a strong execution track record,access to attractive low voltage profit pools and demonstrable pricing power, all underpinned by a relentlessly applied operating model.

·Growth profile underestimated given outsized datacenter exposure. We believe datacenters will be the single most attractive end market in our coverage in the coming years. Legrand, at 24% (from c15% in 2023) is now comparable to Schneider. Given Legrand's market position,we do not believe the market is fully reflecting the likely contribution from DC to Legrand's growth profile, and see incremental upside in the event of a European resi recovery and/or US core office.

·Valuation looks attractive, both absolute and relative.The stock looks attractively valued in absolute terms, albeit towards the higher end of recent historical averages.Importantly, however, the growth outlook in the years ahead is potentially materially different to that of the prior five years, which in our view justifies the current levels.

·Our December 2026 price target is based on a 20x EV/EBITA multiple applied to our 2027 forecasts. The multiple is derived from our reverse DCF approach that takes long-term growth, reinvestment rate, cost of capital, tax rate and normalized margins into account.

·An excellent secular portfolio during a cyclical recovery.Schneider does have the best portfolio when it comes to exposure to the secular drivers, which is why it has performed so well over the past five years. However, there are more cyclically geared names within the electrical group today, and across the wider industrials coverage, which has somewhat stolen the Schneider limelight.

·A change in performance. The Q1 miss and a somewhat uninspiring H1'25 print were uncharacteristic of Schneider.While we don't see any issues or red flags per se, investors are understandably asking why the pace of execution couldn't have been faster on cost mgmt. in IA and on pricing ahead of US tariffs, so the recent de-rating we see is largely justified.S till, we rate SCHN highly and see limited downside to owning the stock at these levels, which may ultimately prove to be an attractive entry point for those taking a multi-year view.

·Catalysts needed: For the shares to 'work', we believe a catalyst of some kind is required, but the relative lack of disclosure at Q3 (sales-only) at a time when most of its other peers are hosting CMD's in Q4, drives our Neutral rating.

Our December 2026 price target is based on a 19x EV/EBITA multiple applied to our 2027 forecasts. We use a normalised EBITA, taking 1% of sales charge to normalise for through-cycle restructuring. The multiple is derived from our reverse DCF approach that takes long-term growth, reinvestment rate,cost of capital, tax rate and normalized margins into account.

Schneider Electric (Neutral; Price Target: €220.00)

- Secular portfolio during a cyclical recovery. Schneider does have the best portfolio when it comes to exposure to the secular drivers, which is why it has performed so well over the past five years. However, there are more cyclically geared names within the electrical group today, and across the wider industrials coverage, which has somewhat stolen the Schneider limelight.- A change in performance. The miss in Q1 and a somewhat uninspiring H1'25 print were uncharacteristic of Schneider. While we don't see any issues or red flags per se, investors are understandably asking why the pace of execution couldn't have been faster on cost management in IA and on pricing ahead of US tariffs coming into effect, so the recent de-rating we see is largely justified. Notwithstanding, we rate the company highly and see limited downside to owning the stock at these levels, which may ultimately prove to be an attractive entry point for those taking a multi-year view.- Catalysts needed: For the shares to 'work', we believe a catalyst of some kind is required, but the relative lack of disclosure at Q3 (sales-only) at a time when most of its other peers are hosting CMD's in Q4, drives our Neutral rating.

Our December 2026 price target is based on a 19x EV/EBITA multiple applied to our 2027 forecasts. We use a normalised EBITA, taking \(1\%\) of sales charge to normalise for throughcycle restructuring. The multiple is derived from our reverse DCF approach that takes longterm growth, reinvestment rate, cost of capital, tax rate and normalized margins into account.
